Michael, Thanks for the response. It does answer my question.

Michael Stack <stack@...> wrote:                                  The time that gets written into the ARC file meta line is the time we 
 started the fetch of the page.  In your extract below, its 
 20061016124449, written in YYYYmmddHHMMSS format (See unix 'date' man 
 page for more on format).
 
 The date you highlight below is the date header written by the server 
 making the HTTP response.  Usually the two will roughly agree -- as they 
 seem to in this case -- but there are no guarantees.
 
 Does this answer your question?
 St.Ack
 
 Anita Bidari wrote:
 >
 > Does the arc file that heretrix writes out contain the date and time 
 > of when it crawled the page?
 > If so , I have a sample arc output below. I see a Date field in the 
 > output (highlighted in red). Does this Date represent when the crawler 
 > crawled the particular page?
 >
 >
 > http://www.cs.indiana.edu/classes/c304/oop-intro.html 129.79.247.195 
 > 20061016124
 > 449 text/html 2414
 > HTTP/1.1 200 OK
 > Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2006 12:44:49 GMT
 > Server: Apache/1.3.29 (Unix) PHP/4.3.6 DAV/1.0.3 mod_ssl/2.8.16 
 > OpenSSL/0.9.7c
 > Last-Modified: Sat, 27 Jul 2002 21:26:58 GMT
 > ETag: "5dd9a-844-3d431022"
 > Accept-Ranges: bytes
 > Content-Length: 2116
 > Connection: close
 > Content-Type: text/html
 >

 > All-new Yahoo! Mail 
 > <http://us.rd.yahoo.com/evt=43256/*http://advision.webevents.yahoo.com/mailbeta>- 
 > Fire up a more powerful email and get things done faster.
 >
